Expectation1: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation1: An external inspector has raised immediate concerns that could halt operations unless issues are resolved
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: A fellow activist is live-streaming from a small demonstration right now and has asked for more people to show up if they are free.
Story: I stared at the email from the inspector, my heart pounding. The report was blunt: unless we addressed the safety concerns by the end of the day, the plant would be shut down. As the lead engineer, everyone was looking to me for answers, for leadership, for a way to keep their jobs safe. My phone buzzed. A message from Maya, my friend and fellow activist, flashed on the screen. “We’re live now—could really use more voices. If you’re free, come down!” I glanced at the clock. The protest was just a few blocks away, and I’d promised to support the cause, to stand up for what I believed in. But here, in this office, people depended on me to keep things running safely and smoothly. My mind raced, torn between the urgent call to action outside and the immediate crisis inside. Both sides expected my full commitment, but I only had one self to give. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding I choose them first.
